um 500 000 workers in 190 different countries around the world who
are have access to a site are registered and active workers on our site and they choose the work that they want to work
on and many of them specialize in different types of work and from
from a business standpoint the businesses typically put work into the system via apis
and so from a business perspective it looks like you're making an api call and a
computer is returning you an answer but in fact a consumer is returning you an answer so
what is similar though to web services other web services is that
mechanical turk is also you know just giving you access to on-demand scalable resources
the fact that we have so many workers in so many different countries means that the work continues around the clock and
is really um independent of geopolitical
issues so for instance there's you know recently in the news obviously the horrible
situation going on in the philippines that is a situation that can be business impacting um and so the one benefit of
mechanical turk is that you're able to really have geo-diversity
because you're able to tap into this workforce on a global basis and so the work really literally can follow the sun

many of the use cases for mechanical turk actually are

and all of that really drives specifically into search relevancy
into that consumer behavior and then ultimately into inventory turnover how successful are

how do we clean the data so that we can provide the right product that the customer is looking for as quickly as

understand the sentiment around those tweets and to really understand what the content is an example that we

uh binders of women and twitter had no idea what does this mean their algorithms had no idea what

so they're you know in in one sense in real time they're acting on the information and deciding advertising

and they're back down and so putting together an algorithm a week and a half after binders of women comes out as a

um and so getting this very quick turnaround is really really important and we're seeing that more and more in

through their systems and through their sites um the uh you know one of the

the way there used to be a litmus test uh you would send it out to a panel of users to

they're you know they're powered with data such as i know how many units are flowing through this store today and they get those high level logistical
view they don't really get insight into that kind of consumer level and they really don't able to answer who's that

so brands have had these questions for you know for forever um and today you know for the last 30 40 years they've
turned to the major market research companies whether it be nielsen iri and what they employ is what's called a
scan panel what this is is they send back basically 50 to 100 000 barcode scanners into homes throughout america
believe it or not and ask those homes to scan in every single product that they buy um as you can imagine it's a quite
high friction experience you have to scan in every product you have to enter the coupon did you what is the price
so on a decent-sized shopping trip that can take anywhere between 10 and 15 minutes and this whole scan panel solution has
been really operates in every major continent in the u.s it's called the national consumer panel used to be called home
scan and again they track 50 to 100 000 households and they're able to record 8000 trips a day
the number of problems you can imagine with that one of them being a scale to cost the operation operate how do you
really scale this out and get more data which is quite challenging two is just data quality
stanford did a large study on the data clearly you don't take everything home you consume a lot of goods on site so a lot
of the data has a lot of gaps and there's a lot of data quality issues so when we started the company or the
whole notion is there's got to be a lower friction way to get this kind of data and 65 of americans are carrying around
a smartphone instead of asking them to you know scan in every single product on an old school barcode scanner just pull
open your phone snap the picture receipt takes 10 to 15 seconds and we'll do the hard work and get all the data
so we have a couple apps in the marketplace for the last year and a half one is called receipt hog and one's called shoparoo and effectively they're
just incentivizing the user that when they're done shopping pull out your smartphone snap your receipt and you'll
be incentivized the receipt hog app is you can earn money yourself it's kind of a fun game
kind of the tamagotchi pig style you get a pig and you feed it receipts but at the end of the day you're you
just basically cash out or via cash or an amazon gift card the second app we have is called shoparoo
and really the incentive there instead of making money yourself it's all around fundraising around a cause we're quite focused on schools right now
so the motivation might might not be very motivating for me to put thirty dollars a year in my pocket snapping
receipts but if a hundred parents are doing at my school and we're going to write a check for three to four grand to
the school that's a very different value proposition and attracts a very different demographic and psychographic
set so between the two apps it allows us to get a kind of a user base that better represents america and kind of create

thousand receipts a day to now we have over about fifty thousand receipts a day
we turn to a strategy about mechanical turks it's called known answers and this is basically the notion that uh
instead of just having one hit and one receipt what we did is we bundled multiple receipts together on one task
with one of those receipts being a known input and output so in this particular example to the right where you see four receipts
one of those is actually a known answer it's been flagged we have someone going in and flag says these are basically our
kind of our label date or our test receipts and from that we're able to synchronously automatically when the
user submits the work gauge their accuracy and and
if the hit was done correctly just based on that one kind of input output it basically allowed us to really scale
out with any of our own review and have this whole task completed by mturk alone and it's a great solution especially
when the problem and the task is relatively simple and has a very concrete known input output
maybe not the best solution if it's a little bit more of a subjective approval rejection process
so the implications of this alone this basically shows our what we are paying a net cost per receipt for that
summary transcription step early early on when we launched you know we're paying over two and a half cents
per receipt the blue represents what we paid directly damn turk and the orange kind of was representing
our review costs on a per receipt level and as you can see very early on we were
basically approving or rejecting every single receipt and our review cost was quite costly when you when you got it
down to a per receipt level so we got we got a little bit more efficient at that and we would score the receipt and we would only approve reject
some receipts at the end of the day we still kind of plateaued and we're paying about two cents a receipt
um the data was still up again to the right and we needed a way to scale this out so we turned to known answers
and you can see the effect over the last three four months it's gone down from about two cents a receipt all the way down to about a cent or receipt
and a lot of that is we no longer have to pay we no longer have to have review people for that we've also been a little bit more efficient in how the worker
completes the hit because they're doing multiple one of them at once they don't go from doing a walgreens
receipt to a target receipt to a walmart we're able to bundle those together so they're doing six walmart at a time six

cent per receipt

keep in mind workers may hate rejections worse than you do they they thrive by having a high approval
